The Unofficial Guide to the University of Michigan (AA) Acronyms & Abbreviations
There's a formal name, and a colloquial name to everything and sometimes it's hard to remember what means what. We've all used them: the Ugli for the Undergraduate Library or EECS for the Electrical Engineering and Computer Science building. For those new to campus, navigating around Ann Arbor can be a challenge when you're first starting out. That's why we’ve created this unofficial guide to the acronyms & abbreviations for places and things in and around University of Michigan Ann Arbor’s campus.
We created this guide as grad students who found it hard to keep up with all the Umich and Ann Arbor lingo and ultimately found ourselves showing up to the wrong classroom on the first day of class, pretending we knew what an acronym was when in came up in conversation and then frantically looking it up later to no avail, or having to be the person that asked what something was and felt silently judged.
We’re here to make your life easier by serving as a resource to mastering campus and Ann Arbor.

A

The Arb: Nichols Arboretum

A large, wooded area east of campus, accessible from Geddes Ave. or from Washington Hts popular for walking, running, and picnics.

The Arcade: Nickels Arcade

A glass-roofed pedestrian walkway with stores that runs from the intersection of State St. and N. University Ave. to Maynard St.

Website

A&AB: Stamps Art & Architecture Building

The home of the Stamps School of Art and Design, this building has labs, studios, and many of the faculty offices, located across the street from Pierpoint Commons.

Website

The [Engin] Arch

The archway through West Hall at the southeast corner of the Diag. Opens onto South and East University streets.

B

BDubs: Buffalo Wild Wings

Nickname for Buffalo Wild Wings, a popular sports bar on State Street known for its wings, TVs, and tap selection.

The Big House

University of Michigan’s football stadium that is one of the most iconic sports venues.

Website

The B-School: Ross School of Business

Michigan's largest and most famous business school, nationally ranked as one of the best programs.

Website

BB: Bursley-Baits

Bursley-Baits Residential Halls, these are actually two separate undergraduate residence halls located on North Campus near the NCRB and Pierpont Commons.

Website

Burlodge: Bursley Hall

Another nickname for Bursley Hall on North Campus.

C

CC Little/CCTC: Central Campus Transit Center

The place on Central Campus where the University transit service (i.e. Blue Buses) and public transit services (i.e. The Ride) pick up and drop off people on both sides of North University Avenue. A common place to see long lines of students waiting to get on a bus to commute between both campuses.

CCRB: Central Campus Recreation Building

The largest Rec on campus, the CCRB is home to a variety of amenities such as basketball courts, a swimming pool, and even a sauna.

Website

The Cube

The large, black metal sculpture in Regents Plaza near the Fleming Administration Building.

CAEN: Computer-Aided Engineering Network

Handles all aspects of computing for the College of Engineering, and runs computer labs on campus.

D

The Diag

The large open space located in the center of Central Campus with many sidewalks running through it in diagonal directions. “The M” is in the center of The Diag.

Website

E

EQ: East Quad

Contrary to its name, the EQ is actually a residential building located on Central Campus that houses roughly 850 students.

Website

EWRE: Environmental & Water Resources Building

Home to the Environemental Engineering department at thew University of Michigan.

F

The Fishbowl: Angel Hall Courtyard

The large glassed-in ITS computing site where Angell, Haven, and Mason Halls meet (located on the “Diag” side of Angell Hall).

The Fish: Ray Fisher Stadium

University of Michigan Baseball Stadium

G

The Grove

The North Campus equivalent of the Central Campus Diag that features walkways and seating. The 4-acre area surrounding the Lurie Bell Tower on North Campus.

Website

The Grad: Harlan Hatcher Graduate Library

Located on the Diag, this is the largest library on campus.

Website

GFL: Gorguze Family Labs

Many student engineering teams, such as the Solar Car and Formula One, call the GFL their home.

H

The Hill

Area of student residence halls on and near Observatory St., east of the walking bridge.

I

IMSB: Intramural Sports Building

This complex is located next to Palmer Field on Central Campus. It features basketball courts, group exercise classes among other facilities.

Website

Ice Cube

Ann Arbor's ice and figure skating rink, open to all.

L

The League: The Michigan League Building

Located on North University Ave, this building contains event space and the Maize cafe on the first floor for snacking.

Website

LBME: Lurie Biomedical Building

Home to the Biomedical Engineering department at the University of Michigan.

M

MUG

The restaurant and seating area on the ground floor of the Michigan Union.

Mojo: Mosher-Jordan Residence Hall

The nickname for the Mosher-Jordan Residence Hall, located in the Hill/Observatory area.

Website

The M

Bronze M in the middle of the Diag

Michigan Time

The tradition of starting every class, meeting or event 10 minutes late.

N

NQ: North Quad

This mixed use building houses roughly 450 undergraduate students while also serving as a hub for the international community at the University.

Website

NCRB: North Campus Recreation Building

A slightly smaller facility located on North Campus next to the Bursley-Baits complex, still with ample facilities such as a running track, lap pool, and a complete weight room.

Website

NAME: Naval Architecture and Marine Engineering

Many submarines and underwater robots have been built here, in the home of the namesake department. Also features an anchor outside the building.

P

The Pringle: https://www.mapquest.com/us/mi/ann-arbor/48109-2200/109-zina-pitcher-pl-42.281877,-83.733548

Part of the Medical School, the ultramodern Biomedical Science Research Building Auditorium (located on Zina Pitcher Place), with its undulating, sloped roof is affectionately known around campus as Pringle Auditorium.

Website

NW: Northwood Residential Community

Northwood is a collection of five different living communities on North Campus. NW I, II, IV, and V are graduate residences, while NW III offers one and two bedroom apartments for undergraduate students.

Website

PML: Phoenix Memorial Laboratory

Originally constructed as a memorial to honor those who lost their lives in WWII, the Phoenix Memorial Laborary is now also home to several cutting-edge engineering labs.

R

The Rock

Giant Boulder on Washtenaw and Hill St corner, often painted over by student organizations.

S

STAMPS: Stamps Auditorium

The Stamps Auditorium located inside the Walgreen Drama Center on North Campus.

Website

Skeeps: Scorekeepers

A popular college sports bar on Central Campus.

SQ: South Quad

The largest of the four Quadrangle Residence Halls, SQ houses nearly 1200 first-year students. Blue Cafe is also located on the ground floor of SQ for a nice treat all year long.

Website

SAB: Student Activities Building

This building is the home to many of the University’s student-orientated administrative functions. If you lose your Mcard, you’ll be making the trip to the SAB for a replacement.

Website

T

TB: Taubman College of Architecture and Urban Planning

Road builders and transportation fans congregate here! Home to the Urban Planning and Architecture departments.

U

UgLi: Undergraduate Library

The Shapiro Undergraduate Library, located on the south side of The Diag, this library is the place to be when stuff needs to get done. It features ample study space and plenty of places to meet with project groups and teams. Traditionally open 24/7, but revised hours may be in place.

Website

UMMA: University of Michigan Museum of Art

The art museum at the University of Michigan

Website

W

The Well: Stockwell Hall

The nickname for Stockwell Hall, a dormitory named after the first woman to be admitted to the university, Madelon Louisa Stockwell.

Website

WQ: West Quad

Like EQ, West Quad is another residence hall for undergraduates located next to the Michigan Union on Central Campus.

Website
